data.title: The Adventures of Picasso (1978)
data.meta_description: Already in his childhood, Pablo Picasso shows talent for painting and is sent to the Academy of Arts in Madrid. He becomes a painter but has to live in Paris in poverty. But one day he is discovered by a rich American millionaire and starts to earn money. But he wastes his talent by painting plates. He meets the famous people of the 1920s; Gertrude Stein, Alice B. Toklas, Appolinaire, Hitler and Churchill.
data.text:
"What's that, Mom?"

"The Eiffel Tower, idiot."

And then the exact same thing with the English Parliament.

You cannot have the excuse “that’s the point”, because that makes it all rather immune. Not to name quite defaulted by length.

But that Adolf H**ler and Winston Churchill scene was pretty much top-tier and broke all records. Never thought I would see the day Magnus Härenstam dressing himself up as Adolf-

Don’t mind Alfred Hitchcock either, standing there and creeping.

If there ever was something to be considered “cringe” this takes the cake. It comes to the point with them playing with it being just that. Somewhat awkward. However the thing is though, for me, it doesn’t get funny. Them playing with…

“And that was the birth of monsterism”

Picassos Äventyr (The Adventures of Picasso) feels very much like a Swedish version of Life of Brian. It’s an extremely free (to say the least) retelling of Pablo Picasso’s life and while the film has an interesting chronology all of it is just used to bring forth an armada of jokes throughout the film’s 100 minutes of runtime. And all of it works perfectly.

Every actor in this film overacts like crazy, but their exaggerated mannerisms fit so well into the style of the film, where it goes all in with every silly joke it can think of. The energy is just amazing and whilst the film is mostly a bunch of skits…
